comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I think it's a dustcart, not a fire engine.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
The Cork Corporation got some stick after the great fire of March 1878 for the poor equipment available to the Fire Brigade.
Who will credit that the Cork Fire Brigade consisted of four men and a superintendent all told, that their equipment consisted of a few antiquated fire reels, without steam engine or jumper, and that the hose was for ten precious minutes attached before a drop could be squeezed out of the hydrant?
It seems they were waiting for someone at the Waterworks to turn the valve on. Full article in Freeman's 28th March 1878 It seems to have shaken things up. At the procession which marked the opening of the Cork Exhibition in 1883
The first place was occupied by the Cork Fire Brigade, with Superintendent Wickham mounted on the new fire engine

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] You and [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] may well be right about the dustcart. From [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner]'s newspaper articles, there's no way this was "fire engine no. 9" at this early period...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: I expect it is a water carrier/distributor alright. Dustcart would get my vote. I agree that it probably isn't related to the fire brigade. (Note however that the city's first fire station was opened in 1893 - about 300 yards from where this photo was taken on Sullivan's Quay). I don't think that climate and the puddles right foreground preclude it being a dustcart. In the summer the unpaved road would get quite dusty with traffic. And the puddles right-foreground may have actually been created by the cart. And in any event the main traffic area looks quite dry. I will have a hunt for any civic service (or one paid for by the merchants on South Mall) that might help confirm.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/20727502@N00] Excellent! Thanks a million...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/20727502@N00] The use of water for other civic works might also be a reason such as for mixing cement at council work sites?  If you look at the patterns on the road the damp patches on the dust is uneven and anybody who has dusted down a cement or dusty surface will know that the water tends to settle into patterns.  The surface tension on the water prevents it from levelling out across the surface and it then soaks in according to the pattern that has formed!  It is most likely a watering cart for keeping the dust down IMHO.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Found reference in Freeman's Journal, November 1860 to watering carts that cost £26 and a dust cart that cost £9 (that was in Blackrock in Dublin). So are we talking about "watering carts" rather than dust carts here?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] As the Cavan man would say "a good quesquion!"  A dust cart was always one that collected the litter and rubbish from houses.  A cart to spread water would be a "watering cart" if you follow that logic!

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] OK. A couple of notes from me and then I have to go back and do some real work. On the National Bank dates. I no longer trust the Archiseek date for 71 South Mall. And have removed the note. I couldn't confirm a precise date for it, but I suspect is in the range that the DIA and ccferrie suggest. (The National Bank had premises at that address going back to the 1840s. There may have been several builds/rebulids/extensions from the 1840s through to the 1880s. But nothing concrete enough to date the photo as I'd thought). I will have a root through other books tonight. In the meantime I'd point the more interested to the 1919 "Cork: It's Trade And Commerce" publication again. Which has a nice piece and photos on banking/trade up and down the Mall. On the dust/watering cart (which I think seems more and more likely), I haven't been able to find anything about a civic or merchant funded service in the city. But I'll have another hunt later. Also, Carol, if you liked the well presented "plaques" publication, you'll like this one on the city's iron work.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
Finding reports in newspapers or water carts taking water from the Liffey in Dublin to put out fires, and from the Irish Times of Monday, 12 November 1860 comes an article describing the destruction of the Kildare Street Club (part of that building is now our Manuscript Department):
... As may be supposed, the fire-plugs afforded but a meagre supply of water, and, as is usual on such occasions, several of the engines were kept idle for a considerable time in the great emergency from the want of water. Owing, however, to the exertions of Mr. White, of the Royal Dublin Society, a plug was opened in the court yard, from which a copious supply of water was poured on the burning pile. The water carts, when they arrived, furnished water in tolerable abundance, but it may be remarked that in no instance was the insufficiency of the water plugs, and the other means usually resorted to on such occasions, more painfully and clearly apparent...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] The meetings of the Dublin Corporation in 1849 are full of discussion of the Gavin fire plug, or Dublin fire plug, invented by Alderman Charles Gavin. There follow adverts placed by grateful citizens whose property has been saved by the Gavin fire plug, and accounts of its effiacacy in combatting fires. I wonder if its use spread elsewhere (e.g. to Cork)?

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach/] No. 63 where you have noted the plate on the wall was the home of Samuel Henry Hobart MD until sometime between 1863 and 1870 when Michael Murphy, Wine Merchant became the occupant.
